title: Citi and the Milken Institute Develop Innovation Lab to Promote Financial Inclusion in Israel
summary: Tel Aviv - Citi announced today it will continue to support the Milken Institute to improve and expand financial inclusion for underserved and unbanked populations in Israel. Recent publications indicate that significant segments of Israel's population are not served by formal financial institutions. Over the last seven years, more than 22 percent of Israeli households are living in poverty, making it the most impoverished country among the world's thirty-four economically developed countries. Small and micro business represents 96 percent of all business in Israel, employ 60 percent of the workforce but receive only 20 percent of bank financing. According to the World Bank, over 12 percent of the population in the bottom 40 percent of the income distribution are unbanked and only 25 percent of that population has savings accounts. Only 17 percent of that population has access to consumer credit.
tag-1: Citi and the Milken Institute Develop Innovation Lab to Promote Financial Inclusion in Israel
tag-2: Tel Aviv – Citi announced today it will continue to support the Milken Institute to improve and expand financial inclusion for underserved and unbanked populations in Israel. Recent publications indicate that significant segments of Israel's population are not served by formal financial institutions. Over the last seven years, more than 22 percent of Israeli households are living in poverty, making it the most impoverished country among the world's thirty-four economically developed countries. Small and micro business represents 96 percent of all business in Israel, employ 60 percent of the workforce but receive only 20 percent of bank financing. According to the World Bank, over 12 percent of the population in the bottom 40 percent of the income distribution are unbanked and only 25 percent of that population has savings accounts. tag-3: This innovation lab planned for the first quarter of 2014 follows a workshop, held in Jerusalem in February 2013, which looked at the best practices from around the world and drew on the expertise of policymakers, practitioners and funders involved with communities whose needs are underserved by the formal financial system in Israel. Read the full report published following the workshop.
tag-4: The Financial Innovations Lab is expected to be attended by senior managers from the Bank of Israel, Ministry of Finance and other important ministries and regulators, as well as international experts and leaders of NGO's and similar financial inclusion organizations. It will focus on developing new regulations, providing specific recommendations on the improvement of access to credit for the un-banked, lower income communities in Israel and the development of microfinance in the country, which it is hoped will lead to the establishing the relevant infrastructure and proving impetus for the initiation of working projects. Financial Innovations Lab® is the Milken Institute's signature tool for generating solutions. Each Lab assembles a multidisciplinary group of investors, industry experts and public officials to tackle a specific financing or policy question.
tag-5: Citi and the Milken Institute partnership are investing almost half a million NIS in this initiative to expand financial access.
tag-6: Bob Annibale, Citi's Head of Microfinance and Community Development, said, "In the background of the move towards expanding access to financial services and supporting inclusive economic growth, Citi with its global experience as a leader in financial inclusion, is leveraging its experience and partnerships with experts in other countries, including the U.S., to support Israel's stated policy objectives and financial infrastructure to provide the unbanked populations with access to credit and savings solutions."
tag-7: Prof. Glenn Yago, Senior Fellow at the Milken Institute and Senior Director of its Israel Center, commented on the upcoming Lab: "The price of inequality in Israel is a barrier to productivity and growth for the larger economy. Israel's future growth will be inadequate and shared unequally without broader access to financial services to increase savings, reduce income and asset poverty, and enable social cohesion required for economic security. The Lab will create a financial roadmap for financial inclusion."
tag-8: Jeremy Bentley, Head of Financial Institutions and Public Sector in Citi Israel, who is leading the relationship on behalf of the Citi, said, "In addition to our business activities in the public sector, I am delighted that as part of our social responsibility we have the opportunity to contribute to the community and help to put in place the infrastructure to make a real change to people's lives."

tag-12: Milken Institute A nonprofit, nonpartisan economic think tank, the Milken Institute believes in the power of finance to shape the future. The Milken Institute produces rigorous, independent economic research — and maximizes its impact by convening global leaders from the worlds of business, finance, policy, academia, and philanthropy. By fostering collaboration between the public and private sectors, we transform great ideas into action.
tag-13: Additional information can be found at http://www.milkeninstitute.org
tag-14: About the Milken Institute Israel Center The Milken Institute Israel Center focuses on developing market-based solutions to the nation's greatest challenges as it transitions from a start-up nation to a global nation. Through the Milken Institute Fellows program, we train some of Israel's best and brightest young professionals in creating pragmatic financing and economic policy solutions, and then deploy them as resources to government ministries, nonprofits and other key organizations. Our applied research and Financial Innovations Labs® serve as a launching pad for transformative change, using innovative financing mechanisms, programs and policies to bridge social, regional, economic, and technological and productivity gaps within Israel and between Israel and the world. Our goal is to accelerate Israel's economic growth, build its human capital and cement its role as a pioneer in addressing global challenges in water, food, education, health, and energy with solutions that others can replicate.
